ただし、鉱石を炉にかけて細かい粉末にすることはできると知っている。 粉にすれば使い方はいくらでもあるはずだ。

I can't believe it's been under my nose this whole time - a hidden magical ore that I mistook for excess bits of rock when mining other valuable ores!  I call it Chimerite because it can look just like mining debris until one's magical senses are honed to be able to detect it.

It's easiest to find in emerald ore, something to do with the structure of emeralds themselves.  Most mages will be able to sense these with only a little bit of magical experience, probably mages that are at least level 5.

Next are diamonds.  While not as easy as emeralds, chimerite can be found here by mages with a little bit more experience, above level 10.

Lastly is coal.  Chimerite is technically there in trace elements, but it takes a finely tuned magical mind to pick up the traces that are large enough to be useable.  I would say no mage under level 20 would see it.

On that point, I should note that the chimerite is also often destroyed as part of the mining process, and isn't always retrievable from every mining attempt.  Emeralds seem to have the best success rate here, followed by diamonds, and then again by coal.

It can be crafted into blocks and back using a crafting table.

sections.value:
I'll need to set up a proper workspace for me to get my spell ideas from my head onto paper.

A table with all the proper places to store everything, paper that is designed to accept magical script, and the proper ink.  I'll need some arcane ash as well.

Once I've got all that together, I can get started.  I'll need to pick a way to shape the spell.  This will be the way it targets the world.  I'm sure there are several shapes that I can learn.

After that, I will need to pick a component so that the spell actually does something.

That alone is enough to make a basic spell.  However, I can think of several aspects of spells that could be modified.  I'll need to add in modifiers to the equation of the spell so that I can change these values.

When my spell is all written out the way I want it, I'll need to give the arcane ash time to imbue the ink into an actual spell recipe and allow the ritual that follows to create the actual spell.  Luckily the table I have in mind will have a spot to do just that.

...I do wonder though if there are ways to make more complicated spells, such as ones that can do multiple things in a single cast?  There must be.

As you cast spells you will build up something called Affinities.  There are six affinities:  Air, Earth, Water, Fire, Ender, and Arcane.  Every affinity has an opposite.

Air opposes Earth.

Water opposes Fire.

Arcane opposes Ender.

A higher affinity will give mana cost discounts on spells with the same affinity (up to 50% at max), and will also increase the mana cost of spells with an opposing affinity.

Lastly, you gain rote experience more quickly of components that share your affinity.

sections.value:
As you cast spells, you begin to learn more about their properties and how they work.  You can see rote progress for each individual spell part (shapes, components, and modifiers) in the Occulus, shown as a yellow line underneath each spell part (turning green when fully rote).

These parts gain experience at different rates.  Once they are rote, you can use them in a book of rote to make spells with single shapes and multiple components.

Modifiers that you learn by rote are always available in rote spells, allowing you to make spells with more components and modifiers than you would normally be able to using the Inscription Table.

There is no crafting process or material cost when making spells in the book of rote, as it represents your memorization of the spell.  You simply make the spell you need at the time.

When placed, it affects an area 50 blocks in front of the vortex face, in a single block column.  It works horizontally as well as vertically.

Additional generators stacked opposite the vortex (for example directly below when facing up) will collectively increase the range of the effect.

sections.value:
The Delegation Station is a block you can use to create complex logic for your constructs.  To start, simply drag a task from the menu on the left to the stage.  Then, drag the blue start node at the top left of the stage to the yellow input node at the top left of the task.  This will set the start of the flow.

Your construct will loop this task once assigned to the Delegation Station.

Every task has two output nodes, a green at the top right and a red just below it.  They represent the outputs of the tasks, green being success or red being failure.  Drag these nodes to the start nodes of other tasks to chain logic.

You can loop a task's output node back in to its input node to cause it to tight loop.  This is useful for performing a task repeatedly until failure, or until construct confusion (see Construct Intelligence).

The construct must be able to engage with at least one of the configured enemy types (ranged attacks, flight, teleportation, or spell casting for flying monsters, buoyancy for water monsters, and perception 20 or lights (consumed) in its inventory for underground.  It will skip any types that it does not meet the criteria for.  For example, setting surface and underground will cause the construct to still perform a surface hunt if it doesn't have the required perception or light sources available.

Affinity also plays a role in the construct's survivability, with wind/arcane protecting from flying monsters, water protecting from aquatic monsters, earth/fire/ender protecting from underground, and earth protecting from surface encounters.
Surface is the least dangerous, followed by water, flying, and finally underground.
Friendly faction mobs encountered during the hunt will serve instead to heal the construct.  Their loot will never be returned.
It is suggested to make use of the health condition task in a lodestar to ensure the construct has healed before leaving on a hunt.  Their natural regeneration can heal them to full, after all.
